content.title: O2の溶融への反応はピークの雪片であった - 独立
content.desc: When the O2 phone network crashed on Thursday at 5am, up to 20m customers were without access to emails, their smart phones turned into useless lumps of plastic. The meltdown – the longest and largest internet blackout in the UK – was caused by a software failure at one of the O2 suppliers, Ericsson. It must have been frustrating not to be able to make calls order pizzas, pay bills and shop for presents, and (not surprisingly) thousands of angry people took to social media to complain. I wonder what these frustrated O2 customers managed to do with their hands while they were walking along t...

content.title: O2は、データブラックアウトが何百万にも及ぶ後の報酬を提供します -  The Telegraph
content.desc: Customers of O2 will be offered mobile credit as compensation after they were left without access to mobile phone data on Thursday following a global network glitch. O2, one of Britain's biggest mobile providers, has said it will contact millions of customers with offers of compensation. Pay monthly O2 customers, business customers and mobile broadband customers will be credited two days of airtime subscription by the end of January. Customers on pay-as-you-go plans will be given a 10pc credit when they top-up their accounts in the New Year, while mobile broadband customers will be given a ...

content.title: O2の停止：ネットワークがダウンした後、私はお金を請求することはできますか？ - テレグラフ
content.desc: As many as 32 million mobile phone users found themselves unable to access internet or apps as O2’s mobile network was hit by a blackout yesterday. The collapse affected not just O2 but also customers of Giffgaff, Tesco Mobile, Sky Mobile and Lycamobile, which use the same network. Many were left stranded as mobile transport services such as Uber were unavailable. Some users also experienced difficulties receiving calls and texts. Mobile providers have previously offered money as compensation for faulty service so if you were affected it may be worthwhile complaining and asking for a refund...

content.title: O2は、数百万のデータが突然停止した後、親善試合を発表 -  The Guardian
content.desc: The mobile phone provider O2 has said its 25 million UK customers will get up to two days’ credit in compensation as a goodwill gesture after a UK-wide outage that left them unable to get online. The technical fault, which resulted in the 3G and 4G services going down and also had an impact on the ability for many people to make or receive calls, affected millions of users on the UK’s second largest mobile network. The outage began at about 5am on Thursday, with 3G capability restored at 9.30pm and the 4G network restored at 3.30am on Friday. By way of apology, O2 is to offer its pay-monthl...

content.title: O2 4Gをオンラインに戻す：1日に数百万回の停止が発生した後、データネットワークが復旧する -  The Independent
content.desc: Mobile network O2 says its data services have been restored after a technical fault left millions of customers unable to access the internet for the best part of a day. The company said it would be closely monitoring its network to prevent further blackouts and was carrying out a review into what caused a “technical glitch” that prevented millions getting online. Most of O2’s 25 million UK customers began to see disruption to data services from around 5am on Thursday. A further seven million users of other smaller mobile networks including Giffgaff, Sky and Tesco, which provide coverage usi...

content.title: O2は、ネットワーク障害からの落ち込みに遭遇しようとする -  Financial Times
content.source_nm: ファイナンシャルタイムズ
content.desc: O2 has offered millions of angry customers credits and discounts after one of Britain’s longest mobile network failures caused chaos on Thursday. It took almost 24 hours for the mobile phone operator to restore data services to its 3G and 4G networks. Brands including Tesco Mobile and GiffGaff, whose networks piggy-back on O2’s, were also hit. Text and voice services were unaffected, but the sheer number of people forced to use them overloaded that network. The chaos went far beyond smartphones and tablets, however. In an illustration of how dependent modern systems are on connectivity, pas...

content.title: O2ネットワークダウン：エリクソンのソフトウェア停止のために何百万もの人々が4Gデータアクセスなしに残った -  The Telegraph
content.desc: Mobile network O2 says its services have been restored after a technical fault left millions of customers unable to get online. The company said it would be closely monitoring data services over the coming days and promised to carry out a review to understand what went wrong. British customers reported not being able to use mobile data to access the internet and the operator's network on Thursday after disruption began at about 5am. On Thursday evening, O2 said 3G data service had started returning and was expected to be fully restored by 9.30pm, while the company reported at 3.30am on Frid...

content.title: O2顧客の報酬：停電後にお金を稼ぐ方法 -  HuffPost UK
content.desc: Mobile giant O2 has confirmed how it will compensate millions of customers following an “unprecedented” network outage. A spokesperson told HuffPost UK that senior staff had explored how best to “make it up to” the 25 million Britons affected by the 24-hour issue with its 4G data services on Thursday. Millions of people who use the service were unable to access mobile internet, while bus stop countdown displays were switched off and in Westminster, at an historic moment in British politics, many politicians and their staff were reportedly unable to access WhatsApp due to the outage. “We’re ...

content.title: ここではばかげた理由がある3200万人のTelefonica（O2）ユーザーが昨日の4Gデータにさよならを振った - フォーブス
content.desc: O2 suffered a massive outage after a minor mistake (AP Photo/Matthias Schrader) Yesterday was not a good day for users of the second biggest mobile network operator in the United Kingdom, Telefonica UK which is better known as O2, as its customers lost access to the 4G network. Nor was it a good day for Telefonica itself which also owns GiffGaff and provides virtual network access to users of Lyca Mobile, Sky Mobile and Tesco Mobile who also found themselves without 4G data. In total, 32 million users found themselves without data or SMS message services from breakfast to bedtime. Users of ...

content.title: O2 4Gはいつオンラインに戻りますか？ネットワークは最終的にインターネットが再び働く時の更新を提供する - 独立系
content.desc: O2's data network will be back online by tomorrow morning, its parent company has finally announced. The announcement finally brings a close to mass confusion as O2 customers tried to work out why their 4G connections refused to work. But it means that they will have been without internet for more than a day, after the internet broke early this morning. Until now, all companies involved would only say that they were fixing the problem as soon as possible, and that they were working hard on bringing an end to the issues. Now the two companies say they are "aiming" to have the problems fixed ...

content.title: O2ダウン：4Gとデータはまだ停止として動作していないGiffGaffとテスコモバイル - 独立
content.desc: O2’s internet service is down, leaving customers of the network unable to get online. The problems mean those companies that share its network – such as GiffGaff and Tesco Mobile – are also being hit by the problems. Calls can still be made by customers despite the fact 4G data connections are broken, O2 said, though some users reported having so signal at all. Affected phones, which may be every single device registered to the network, simply fail to show any kind of data connection and will not connect even when turned off and back on or when other workarounds are tried, according to user...

content.title: 政府は、携帯電話ユーザーがダウンした場合にネットワークを切り替えることを検討するよう促した -  The Telegraph
content.desc: Mobile phone operators must allow "internal roaming" to stop customers being hit by data outages, an MP has said, as a major O2 data failure has reignited calls for a Government inquiry. It comes after as many as 32 million mobile phone customers were hit by a software error which caused them to lose internet access and the ability to make and receive calls for most of Thursday. Yesterday O2 announced it would "make it right" with affected customers by refunding them for lost service, but consumer and small business groups urged those who had lost out to claim additional compensation where ...

content.title: O2の停止：30m以上のモバイルユーザーがオンラインにアクセスできない -  The Guardian
content.desc: More than 30 million customers of mobile providers including O2, Tesco Mobile and Sky Mobile were unable to get online on Thursday, with many also unable to make or receive phone calls, after a technical fault caused a UK-wide outage unlikely to be fixed until Friday morning. The problem hit O2’s entire network and also affected companies that use its platform, including its subsidiary Giffgaff and Lycamobile. The blackout of 3G and 4G services, which prevented customers from getting online on their phones, began at about 4am on Thursday. O2’s chief executive, Mark Evans, told the BBC the c...

content.title: トランスポートネットワークとしてのO2 4Gとインターネットユーザーが何百万人もの顧客を獲得できない -  The Independent
content.desc: O2's internet network is suffering an outage. And O2's customers are outraged. The carrier's 4G problems have hit the networks 25 million customers, as well as those using networks that rely on its infrastructure, like GiffGaff and Tesco Mobile. But it is also causing problems in places that rely on O2's network coverage for other important services. Transport for London's live timetables, for instance – which allow people to see accurately when a bus is about to turn up at any given stop – appears to have broken and is showing that no buses are arriving. That appears to rely on O2's data c...

content.title: O2 4Gダウン：Tesco MobileとGiffGaffのユーザーも障害に直面しているため、ソフトウェアの問題によりデータとネットワークが機能しない -  The Independent
content.desc: O2 has finally explained why its customers have been without internet for hours. The phone network has blamed a software problem at one of its suppliers, suggesting that the issue could be affecting other carriers too. Customers of O2 – as well as other networks that rely on its infrastructure, like GiffGaff and Tesco Mobile – have been unable to get online since early in the morning. Phones simply cannot connect to the internet and there is very little their users can do. There appears to be very little progress with fixing it. But the company has finally explained why the problem has occu...

content.title: エリクソンのソフトウェア問題の後、数百万人がスマートフォンの停止で打撃 - ファイナンシャルタイムズ
content.source_nm: ファイナンシャルタイムズ
content.desc: Millions of mobile phone users around the world have been unable to use their smartphones after a software issue in systems provided by Ericsson caused major disruption. Japanese smartphone users on the SoftBank network and British customers on O2 were left frustrated on Thursday by a significant outage and a lack of clarity about when service would be resumed. O2’s 4G network crashed around 5am local time in the UK, leaving customers without data access. O2 said one of its suppliers had identified a “global software issue” and it was working with the company to resolve the issue as quickly...

content.title: O2データダウン：数千人の顧客がデータなしで放置した後にネットワークが停止を調査 -  HuffPost UK
content.desc: Mobile network O2 has said it is investigating a technical fault that has left thousands of mobile customers unable to get online. UK customers reported not being able to use mobile data to access the internet and other services on the company’s network from around 5:30am on Thursday. It has confirmed engineers are working to fix the issue. We are aware our customers are unable to use data this morning. Our technical teams are working on the issue with high priority. We are really sorry and working as hard and as fast as we can to fix this. Please keep an eye on our status checker: https://...

content.title: O2、4Gネットワ​​ークサービスの復旧を発表 -  Financial Times
content.source_nm: ファイナンシャルタイムズ
content.desc: O2 said service on its 4G mobile data network had been restored early on Friday morning, nearly a day after a software issue in systems provided by Ericsson led to an outage that left millions of customers in the UK without data access. “We can now report that our 4G network has been restored,” said an O2 spokesperson in a statement. “Our technical teams will continue to monitor service performance closely over the next few days to ensure we remain stable. A review will be carried out with Ericsson to understand fully what happened.” O2, which is owned by Spain’s Telefónica, has 32m custome...

content.title: O2、ソフトウェア不具合後にインターネットサービスを復活させる - ロイターオンライン調査
content.desc: O2's 4G cellular network has been restored, the British mobile operator said on Friday, following a software glitch which caused smartphone users to lose internet access. "A review will be carried out with Ericsson to understand fully what happened", said O2, which is owned by Spain's Telefonica. O2 and Softbank Group Corp's mobile phone unit, both software customers of Ericsson, reported disruptions to data services on Thursday that affected millions of customers. (Reporting by Shubham Kalia in Bengaluru; Editing by Sai Sachin Ravikumar)
